title: Personal Hygiene for Food Handlers
legalBasis: EU Regulation (EC) No 852/2004, Annex II, Chapter VIII on personal hygiene; Royal Decree 109/2010 on food handler training; General Principles of Food Hygiene (Codex Alimentarius CXC 1-1969)
summary:
Personal hygiene of food handlers is one of the most critical factors in preventing foodborne illness. Food handlers are a primary potential source of contamination, capable of transferring pathogenic microorganisms from their hands, clothing, or bodies to food, food-contact surfaces, and equipment. EU Regulation 852/2004, Annex II, Chapter VIII requires every person working in a food handling area to maintain a high degree of personal cleanliness and wear suitable, clean, and where necessary, protective clothing.

Effective personal hygiene encompasses multiple elements: proper handwashing technique and frequency, appropriate work clothing and protective equipment, personal health monitoring and illness reporting, exclusion of jewelry and other contaminants, management of cuts and wounds, and overall cleanliness standards. Each element is essential — handwashing alone is not sufficient if a food handler is wearing contaminated clothing or has an untreated wound.

Personal hygiene failures are a leading cause of foodborne disease outbreaks. Norovirus outbreaks frequently result from ill food handlers continuing to work. Staphylococcal food poisoning often traces to food handlers with infected wounds. Proper personal hygiene practices, combined with health surveillance and a workplace culture that encourages reporting illness, form an essential barrier against contamination. Every food handler must understand that their personal hygiene directly impacts customer safety.
keyPoints: Hands must be washed frequently using correct technique: wet, soap, scrub 20+ seconds, rinse, dry
Work clothing must be clean, light-colored, and changed daily or when visibly soiled
Hair must be fully restrained with hats, caps, or hairnets to prevent hair contamination
Jewelry, watches, and personal items must be removed before handling food
Cuts and wounds must be covered with blue waterproof plasters and, for hand wounds, gloves worn over
Food handlers experiencing vomiting, diarrhea, fever, or infected wounds must not handle food and must report to management
Smoking, eating, drinking, and chewing gum are prohibited in food preparation areas
Personal hygiene standards apply equally to all staff in food handling areas including managers, trainees, and temporary workers

sections.heading: 1. Hand Hygiene — The Critical Control
sections.content:
Hands are the primary vehicle for transferring microorganisms to food. Even hands that appear clean can carry millions of bacteria, viruses, and parasites. Proper handwashing is the single most important personal hygiene measure for food handlers. EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that every person working in a food handling area ensures their hands are kept clean and, where necessary, washes their hands immediately before handling food, after touching contaminated materials, and after using the toilet.

Effective handwashing requires both correct technique and appropriate frequency. The technique must physically remove microorganisms from all hand surfaces, including between fingers, under nails, and around thumbs — areas commonly missed. The frequency must be sufficient to prevent contamination transfer as food handlers move between tasks with different contamination risks. A food handler who washes hands perfectly but infrequently, or who washes hands frequently but poorly, achieves inadequate protection.

Handwashing facilities must be appropriately located and equipped. Sinks designated for handwashing must be separate from food preparation sinks and provided with hot and cold running water, liquid soap, and hygienic hand drying facilities (disposable paper towels or air dryers). Hand sanitizer or alcohol gel is not a substitute for handwashing, though it can provide additional protection when used after proper handwashing.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Correct Handwashing Technique
subsections.content:
The correct handwashing procedure involves multiple steps, each essential for effective microbial removal. First, wet hands thoroughly under running water (warm water is more comfortable and encourages adequate duration, but temperature is less critical than technique and duration). Apply liquid soap — bar soap can harbor bacteria and should not be used in food environments. Rub hands together vigorously to create a lather, ensuring all surfaces are covered.

Scrub all hand surfaces systematically: palms, backs of hands, between all fingers, thumbs (often forgotten), fingernails and nail beds (scrubbing with nails of opposite hand), and wrists. The entire handwashing process should take at least 20 seconds of scrubbing — many people rush this step. Rinse thoroughly under running water, ensuring all soap is removed. Dry hands completely using disposable paper towels or a hand dryer — damp hands transfer bacteria more readily than dry hands. If using paper towels, use the towel to turn off the tap to avoid recontamination.

subsections.heading: 1.2 When to Wash Hands
subsections.content:
Food handlers must wash hands at critical moments to prevent cross-contamination. Mandatory handwashing moments include: before starting work and after any break; before handling ready-to-eat food; after handling raw food (particularly raw meat, poultry, fish, eggs); after touching contaminated surfaces, equipment, or waste; after using the toilet; after touching face, hair, nose, or any part of the body; after sneezing, coughing, or blowing nose; after handling cleaning chemicals or dirty cloths; after eating, drinking, or smoking (in designated break areas only); and after any activity that could contaminate hands.

In practice, kitchen staff should be washing hands very frequently — experienced chefs may wash hands dozens of times per shift as they move between tasks. The key principle is to wash hands whenever moving from a potentially contaminating task to a task involving ready-to-eat food or clean equipment. When in doubt, wash hands — it is impossible to wash hands too often in a food handling environment.

subsections.heading: 1.3 Hand Sanitizers and Gloves
subsections.content:
Alcohol-based hand sanitizers or gels can provide additional protection when used correctly, but they are not a substitute for handwashing. Sanitizers are less effective when hands are visibly soiled and may not be effective against certain pathogens such as norovirus. If sanitizers are used, they should be in addition to regular handwashing, not instead of it. Sanitizers are most appropriately used after handwashing for additional protection before handling high-risk foods.

Disposable gloves can provide a barrier but can also create a false sense of security. Gloves do not eliminate the need for handwashing — hands must be washed before putting on gloves and after removing them. Gloves must be changed as frequently as hands would be washed: between handling raw and ready-to-eat foods, after any contaminating event, and when torn or damaged. Gloves should be single-use and discarded after each task. Food handlers must understand that gloves can become contaminated just as easily as bare hands and require the same care to prevent cross-contamination.

sections.heading: 2. Protective Clothing and Appearance
sections.content:
Appropriate work clothing serves multiple functions: it protects food from contamination by the food handler's personal clothing and body, it protects the food handler from food splashes and heat, and it projects professionalism and cleanliness to customers. EU Regulation 852/2004 requires food handlers to wear suitable, clean, and where appropriate, protective clothing. The regulation allows flexibility for establishments to define 'suitable' clothing for their specific operations, but general principles apply across the sector.

Work clothing should be clean at the start of each shift, light-colored (so that soiling is immediately visible), dedicated to work (not worn for commuting or outside activities), and made of washable material. Full chef's whites in a formal restaurant kitchen, a clean t-shirt and apron in a casual establishment, or a full protective overall in a food production facility are all appropriate within their contexts. The key is that clothing is clean, fit for purpose, and changed when soiled.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Work Clothing Standards
subsections.content:
At minimum, food handlers should wear a clean top (shirt, chef's jacket, or tunic) and trousers or skirt in a light color. An apron provides additional protection and can be changed during the shift if soiled. Footwear must be clean, closed-toe, slip-resistant, and appropriate for kitchen environments — no canvas shoes or open sandals. In kitchen environments with heat and liquid hazards, sturdy footwear provides important safety protection.

Clothing should fit properly — excessively loose clothing can contact food or get caught in equipment, while excessively tight clothing may be uncomfortable and unhygienic. Pockets in chef's jackets should not be used for storing personal items (phones, pens, notepads) that could fall into food. Outdoor clothing (jackets, coats) and personal bags must be stored in designated areas away from food handling zones and should never be brought into food preparation areas.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Hair Restraints
subsections.content:
Hair is a significant contamination hazard — human hair can carry bacteria and the presence of hair in food is highly objectionable to customers. All food handlers with hair that could contact food or food-contact surfaces must wear effective hair restraints. For long hair, this means complete coverage with a hat, hairnet, or cap. Short hair should also be covered or, at minimum, kept very clean and tidy. Beards and mustaches should be neatly trimmed or covered with beard nets in high-risk food handling areas.

Hair restraints must be put on before entering the food handling area and remain in place throughout the shift. Food handlers should avoid touching their hair while working — if hair is touched, hands must be washed before resuming work. Hairpins, clips, and bands should be secure to prevent them falling into food. Staff should be reminded that seeing hair in food is one of the most common and serious customer complaints and is easily preventable with proper restraints.

subsections.heading: 2.3 Jewelry and Personal Items
subsections.content:
Jewelry and personal items pose multiple hazards: physical contamination if items fall into food, harbourage of bacteria in settings and crevices that cannot be effectively cleaned, and interference with handwashing and glove use. All jewelry except a plain wedding band should be removed before commencing food handling work. This includes rings, bracelets, watches, necklaces, earrings (other than small studs), and visible body piercings.

The restriction on jewelry is for food safety, not aesthetics. Rings other than a plain band have settings that harbor bacteria and interfere with handwashing. Watches prevent cleaning of the wrist area. Bracelets and necklaces can physically contact food. Earrings and facial jewelry can fall into food if dislodged. If staff are reluctant to remove jewelry, explain the food safety rationale and provide secure personal storage. Wedding bands, if worn, should be included in thorough handwashing.

sections.heading: 3. Management of Cuts, Wounds, and Skin Conditions
sections.content:
Cuts, wounds, sores, and skin infections are potential sources of pathogenic bacteria, particularly Staphylococcus aureus which commonly colonizes skin and can cause food poisoning if transferred to food in sufficient numbers. Any break in the skin must be properly covered to prevent contamination of food. EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that persons known or suspected to be suffering from, or to be a carrier of, a disease likely to be transmitted through food, or afflicted with infected wounds, skin infections, or diarrhea must not be permitted to handle food or enter food handling areas.

Minor cuts and wounds that are properly covered may not preclude food handling, but infected wounds, boils, or extensive skin conditions require temporary reassignment away from food contact work. The decision should be based on the location and severity of the condition and the type of food handling work. A food safety culture where staff feel comfortable reporting wounds and skin problems without fear of losing shifts is essential for effective management.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Covering Cuts and Wounds
subsections.content:
All cuts, burns, sores, and grazes must be covered with a waterproof dressing before handling food. The food industry standard is brightly colored (typically blue) waterproof plasters that are easily visible if they fall into food. Blue is used because it is not a natural food color and is easily detected. Some establishments use metal-detectable plasters that can be identified by metal detection systems if they enter the food production line.

For cuts on hands or fingers, a waterproof plaster alone may not provide adequate protection — a disposable glove should be worn over the plaster to prevent the plaster becoming dislodged and to provide an additional barrier. Gloves should be changed frequently as they are more likely to tear or puncture when worn over plasters. If a plaster or glove is missing, all food prepared since the item was last known to be intact must be inspected, and if the item is not found, the food may need to be discarded.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Infected Wounds and Skin Conditions
subsections.content:
Infected wounds (showing signs of pus, swelling, redness, heat, or pain), boils, sties, and other skin infections must not be in contact with food, food-contact surfaces, or equipment. If the infection is on hands or exposed parts of the body, the food handler must not work in food preparation until the infection is healed or adequately controlled under medical supervision. The food handler should be temporarily reassigned to non-food-contact duties if available, or excluded from work if necessary.

Chronic skin conditions such as eczema or psoriasis require individual assessment. If the condition is well-controlled, properly treated, and covered, and if the food handler maintains rigorous hand hygiene, food handling may be possible. However, weeping or broken skin on hands makes effective handwashing difficult and may require exclusion from food contact work. Medical advice may be needed to determine when a food handler with a skin condition can safely resume food contact work.

subsections.heading: 3.3 Reporting and Documentation
subsections.content:
Food handlers must be trained and encouraged to report any cuts, wounds, or skin conditions to their supervisor. A simple reporting system should be in place — a first aid log or wound reporting form. The supervisor should assess the situation, ensure the wound is properly covered, and determine whether the food handler can continue in food contact work or requires temporary reassignment.

Documentation serves multiple purposes: it tracks the use of first aid supplies, provides evidence of proper wound management if a food safety incident occurs, and demonstrates compliance with food safety requirements. The record should note the date, nature and location of the injury, first aid provided, and any work restrictions imposed. Follow-up should be documented if the injury requires ongoing monitoring.

sections.heading: 4. Health Surveillance and Illness Reporting
sections.content:
Food handlers suffering from or carrying infections that can be transmitted through food pose a serious risk to public health. EU Regulation 852/2004 requires that persons known or suspected to be suffering from, or carriers of, a disease likely to be transmitted through food must not be permitted to handle food. Key symptoms that should trigger exclusion or restriction include vomiting, diarrhea, fever, jaundice, and sore throat with fever.

The challenge is ensuring that food handlers report symptoms. Many food handlers, particularly those on zero-hours contracts or without sick pay, feel pressure to work when unwell. Creating a food safety culture where reporting illness is expected and supported, where sick pay is provided, and where managers lead by example in staying home when ill, is essential. The short-term cost of providing sick pay is far less than the cost of a foodborne illness outbreak traced to an ill food handler.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Symptoms Requiring Exclusion
subsections.content:
Food handlers experiencing vomiting or diarrhea must not work in food handling areas and must be excluded from work until at least 48 hours after symptoms have completely resolved. This 48-hour exclusion period is critical because viral gastroenteritis (particularly norovirus) can be transmitted even after symptoms cease. The food handler should not return until they have been completely symptom-free for 48 hours and feel fully recovered.

Other symptoms requiring assessment and possible exclusion include fever (which may indicate infection), jaundice (indicating possible hepatitis A, a serious foodborne pathogen), sore throat with fever (possible streptococcal infection), skin infections or boils (as discussed above), and discharge from eyes, nose, or ears (possible infection). A food handler with any of these symptoms should report to their manager, who should assess the situation and, when in doubt, exclude the food handler from work until medical clearance is obtained.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Reporting of Diagnosed Infections
subsections.content:
Food handlers diagnosed with certain infections must report these to their employer and may require prolonged exclusion and medical clearance before returning to work. Notifiable infections particularly relevant to food handlers include typhoid and paratyphoid fever, hepatitis A, shigellosis, E. coli O157 and other STEC infections, and norovirus. In some cases, health authorities may require that food handlers be proven to be no longer excreting the pathogen (through stool samples) before clearance to return to work.

If a food handler is diagnosed with a notifiable foodborne infection, the employer should immediately notify the local health authority, who will investigate potential exposure of customers and may require temporary closure or enhanced cleaning and disinfection. All food prepared by the affected food handler during the infectious period may need to be traced. This underscores why early reporting of symptoms and exclusion from work is so important — it prevents exposure of large numbers of customers to infection.

subsections.heading: 4.3 Creating a Culture of Reporting
subsections.content:
The success of health surveillance depends on food handlers feeling safe to report symptoms. This requires a supportive workplace culture and practical policies. Employers should provide paid sick leave so that food handlers do not face financial hardship from staying home when ill. Managers should respond positively when staff report illness, thanking them for protecting customers rather than creating pressure to work. Clear policies should be communicated during induction and reinforced regularly.

Managers must lead by example — if a manager works while suffering from vomiting or diarrhea, staff will feel pressured to do the same. Regular training should remind all staff of their responsibility to report symptoms and reassure them that they will be supported in doing so. A simple illness reporting procedure — a designated phone number or person to contact, with clear criteria for when to report — makes compliance easier. Documentation of reported illnesses provides evidence of an effective food safety culture.

sections.heading: 5. Personal Habits and Behavior
sections.content:
Beyond specific hygiene practices, food handlers' overall behavior and habits significantly impact food safety. Certain behaviors are prohibited in food handling areas because they pose contamination risks: smoking, eating, drinking (except from designated cups in safe areas), chewing gum, tasting food with fingers or re-using tasting spoons, touching face or hair, and coughing or sneezing over food or food-contact surfaces.

These restrictions can feel onerous, particularly during long shifts, but each is based on clear contamination risk. Smoking transfers bacteria from mouth to hands to food and is also a fire hazard. Eating and drinking in food preparation areas risk contamination from personal food and containers. Chewing gum increases salivation and risks the gum falling into food. Touching face or hair transfers bacteria to hands. The key is to provide designated break areas where staff can eat, drink, and relax away from food handling zones.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Prohibited Activities in Food Areas
subsections.content:
Smoking is strictly prohibited in all indoor workplaces in Spain under Law 42/2010. Beyond legal compliance, smoking in or near food areas poses serious contamination risks. Smokers must use designated outdoor areas well away from food storage and preparation zones. After smoking, hands must be thoroughly washed before returning to food handling work — ideally, smokers should also change their work clothing if it has absorbed smoke odor.

Eating and drinking by staff must only occur in designated break areas away from food preparation and storage. The only exception is drinking water from a covered container that can be safely stored away from food preparation areas — some kitchens provide designated drinking water stations. Tasting food during preparation is necessary but must be done hygienically: use a clean spoon to remove a sample to a dish, taste from the dish using a separate spoon, and place the used spoon directly in the wash area. Never taste directly from cooking vessels or reuse tasting spoons without washing.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Respiratory Hygiene
subsections.content:
Coughing and sneezing expel droplets containing bacteria and viruses that can contaminate food and surfaces. Food handlers should never cough or sneeze over food, food-contact surfaces, or equipment. If a food handler needs to cough or sneeze, they should turn away from food, cover their mouth and nose with a tissue or the crook of their elbow (not hands), dispose of the tissue immediately, and wash their hands thoroughly before resuming work.

Food handlers with persistent coughing or sneezing should be assessed for illness — these symptoms may indicate respiratory infection that could require exclusion from work. Even without fever or other symptoms, persistent coughing or sneezing in food preparation areas is unacceptable. If symptoms are due to allergies and the food handler is not ill, they should be provided with appropriate allergy management and reminded to maintain strict respiratory hygiene and frequent handwashing.

subsections.heading: 5.3 Mobile Phones and Personal Items
subsections.content:
Mobile phones are contamination vectors — studies consistently show that phones carry high levels of bacteria, often including enteric pathogens. Mobile phones must not be used in food preparation areas. Phones should be stored in lockers or staff areas and only used during breaks away from food zones. If managers or staff must use phones for work purposes (e.g., receiving delivery notifications), the phone should be treated as a contaminating item and hands washed thoroughly after use.

Personal items such as wallets, keys, makeup, and medications must not be brought into food preparation areas. Designated storage areas (lockers, staff room) should be provided for personal belongings. If staff must carry items such as asthma inhalers or essential medications, a manager should be informed and secure storage in an office or first aid area arranged. The principle is simple: only work-related items should be in food preparation areas, and anything brought in from outside is a potential contamination source.

sections.heading: 6. Training and Enforcement
sections.content:
Knowledge of personal hygiene requirements is necessary but not sufficient — food handlers must actually apply the knowledge in daily practice. This requires comprehensive initial training, regular refresher training, ongoing supervision and monitoring, and a workplace culture that values and enforces hygiene standards. Royal Decree 109/2010 requires all food handlers to receive training in food hygiene commensurate with their work activity.

Training should be provided before a food handler begins work, should be practical and tailored to the specific establishment, and should be reinforced regularly. Visual reminders such as handwashing technique posters at sinks, hygiene rules displayed in staff areas, and regular brief team talks about hygiene standards help maintain awareness. Managers must actively supervise hygiene practices and provide immediate corrective feedback when standards slip.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Initial and Ongoing Training
subsections.content:
All new food handlers should receive personal hygiene training as part of their induction before they begin work. Training should cover: correct handwashing technique and when to wash hands, work clothing and protective equipment requirements, hair restraint requirements, jewelry and personal item restrictions, management of cuts and wounds, illness reporting requirements and symptoms that require exclusion, prohibited behaviors in food areas, and the consequences of poor hygiene for food safety and the business.

Training should be practical — demonstrate correct handwashing, show examples of appropriate work clothing and hair restraints, practice tasting procedures. Assessment helps verify understanding — ask trainees to explain when they would wash hands, or to demonstrate handwashing technique. Document all training including trainee name, date, topics covered, and assessment results. Refresher training should be provided annually and whenever hygiene standards are observed to be slipping or after any food safety incident.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Supervision and Monitoring
subsections.content:
Managers and supervisors must actively monitor personal hygiene practices and provide immediate feedback when standards are not met. Monitoring should be continuous during operations — observe whether staff are washing hands at appropriate moments, whether work clothing is clean, whether hair restraints are properly worn. If poor practice is observed, provide immediate corrective coaching in a respectful manner that reinforces the food safety rationale.

Periodic structured observations using a personal hygiene audit checklist can provide systematic assessment. The checklist might cover: handwashing frequency and technique, cleanliness of work clothing, proper hair restraint, absence of jewelry, appropriate management of cuts and wounds, no prohibited activities observed. Audit results should be documented, trends analyzed, and additional training or corrective measures implemented if gaps are identified. Recognize and praise good hygiene practices to reinforce positive behavior.

subsections.heading: 6.3 Enforcement and Accountability
subsections.content:
Clear hygiene standards should be established as conditions of employment, documented in employee handbooks or contracts. All staff should sign acknowledgment that they understand the hygiene requirements and the consequences of non-compliance. A progressive disciplinary process should be established for repeated or serious hygiene violations: first offense might warrant a verbal warning and retraining, repeated offenses might require written warnings, and persistent non-compliance or serious violations (such as working while suffering from vomiting/diarrhea) may warrant dismissal.

Enforcement must be consistent and apply to all staff equally including managers, chefs, and long-serving employees. Inconsistent enforcement undermines food safety culture — if senior staff are observed violating hygiene standards without consequence, other staff will follow suit. The goal is not to create a punitive environment but to establish that personal hygiene is a non-negotiable requirement for food safety and that everyone is accountable for maintaining standards.

checklists.title: Personal Hygiene Daily Self-Check
items: Hands washed before starting work and before handling food
Work clothing is clean and appropriate for my role
Hair is completely covered with hat, cap, or hairnet
All jewelry except plain wedding band removed before work
Any cuts or wounds covered with blue waterproof plaster (and glove if on hand)
Fingernails are clean, short, and free of nail polish or artificial nails
I am not experiencing vomiting, diarrhea, fever, or other symptoms requiring exclusion
Mobile phone and personal items stored in designated area, not in food preparation zone
I will wash hands frequently throughout shift at all required moments
I will report any hygiene concerns or symptoms to my supervisor

checklists.title: Manager's Personal Hygiene Supervision Checklist
items: All food handlers wearing clean, appropriate work clothing at start of shift
Hair restraints properly worn by all staff throughout shift
Handwashing observed at appropriate moments (start of work, after breaks, between tasks)
No jewelry visible on food handlers except plain wedding bands
Any cuts or wounds properly covered with blue plasters and gloves if necessary
No prohibited activities observed (smoking, eating, drinking, mobile phone use in food areas)
Staff illness reporting system functioning — any reported symptoms assessed and followed up
Handwashing facilities properly stocked (soap, paper towels, hot and cold water)
Personal hygiene training up to date for all staff
Any hygiene violations addressed immediately with coaching and corrective action

checklists.title: Monthly Personal Hygiene System Review
items: Review personal hygiene training records — all staff current?
Conduct structured personal hygiene observation audit using checklist
Review illness reporting records — any concerning trends or gaps?
Check handwashing facilities — all functioning correctly with adequate supplies?
Review and replenish stock of blue plasters, disposable gloves, and hand soap
Assess work clothing condition — any staff requiring replacement uniforms?
Review any customer complaints related to hygiene or staff appearance
Assess effectiveness of hygiene supervision and monitoring
Provide refresher training or team talk on personal hygiene if gaps identified
Update personal hygiene procedures if needed and communicate changes to staff
Document review and file with HACCP verification records

bestPractices: Make handwashing easy and habitual by locating sinks strategically, keeping them well-stocked, and displaying technique reminders
Provide clean work clothing or laundry service so that financial barriers do not prevent staff from maintaining clothing standards
Create a food safety culture where reporting illness is expected and supported with sick pay, not punished with lost shifts
Lead by example — managers must visibly maintain the same hygiene standards they expect from staff
Use visual management techniques: posters, signs, and regular reminders keep personal hygiene standards front-of-mind
Integrate personal hygiene into daily briefings and team talks, not just annual training
Provide positive feedback and recognition when good hygiene practices are observed to reinforce desired behaviors
Make personal hygiene requirements clear during recruitment and induction so expectations are understood from the start

glossary.Blue Plasters: Brightly colored (typically blue) waterproof dressings used in food environments because the color is easily visible if the plaster falls into food
glossary.Cross-Contamination: The transfer of harmful bacteria or other microorganisms from one surface or substance to another, often from hands or contaminated equipment to food
glossary.Food Handler: Any person working in a food business who handles food or food-contact surfaces, including preparation, processing, cooking, serving, storing, or distributing food
glossary.Hand Sanitizer: An alcohol-based gel or liquid that reduces bacterial counts on hands but does not replace handwashing, particularly when hands are visibly soiled
glossary.Pathogen: A microorganism (bacteria, virus, parasite, or fungus) capable of causing disease in humans
glossary.Potable Water: Water that meets legal drinking water standards and is safe for human consumption and food use
glossary.Ready-to-Eat Food: Food that is intended to be consumed without further cooking or processing that would eliminate microorganisms
glossary.Staphylococcus aureus: A bacterium commonly found on human skin and in the nose that can cause food poisoning if transferred to food and allowed to multiply
glossary.Vector: An agent (person, object, or surface) that carries and transmits infectious microorganisms from one source to another
glossary.Waterproof Dressing: A plaster or bandage that is impermeable to water and prevents moisture, bacteria, or the dressing itself from contaminating food
